title: Is 'everyone else is doing it' a valid reason for unethical and immoral behavior? - Quora

response.answer_text: No. It reflects low moral fibre - the herd mentality - a failure to stand up and be counted - a fear of standing out from the crowd. It paves the way forward for cowards and bullies. It’s responsible for alcoholism, drugs, crime, bad driving habits, sexism, racism and all sorts of other anti-social or socially destructive behaviour. When you say “a valid reason”, I take it you mean “an excuse”. The whole point of ethics and morals is to set the standard that the society in which a person lives is expected to meet. By setting those standards, the society has already decided the issue. Everyone is expected to meet those standards. And frankly, anyone who doesn’t want to meet the standards that society sets should go and live somewhere else. The reason for many of the laws we have is that some people do NOT want to behave in an ethical or moral manner. So they have to be forced to. It is also a large part of the reason for our police force and other law enforcement agencies. A long while ago, I spent 8 years of my life in a law enforcement role, responsible for the administration and enforcement of the laws which applied in this state at the time, regulating companies and the behaviour of their directors and other officers. (Those laws were later taken over by the Federal government - at the time when I was involved, they were state laws). And when I commenced in that role, little or nothing had been done to enforce the law. So I was confronted with a huge mess, where company directors etc either weren’t fully aware of what they were expected to do - or did know, and simply didn’t care - just wanted to do as they pleased. Things changed very smartly when I started prosecuting them for breaching the law. And by the time I left, corporate crime at any serious level had “re-located” to other parts of the country. What I found particularly distasteful was the number of times people tried to interfere with my power to prosecute such breaches - and the identity of some of the people who tried it.

Is "everyone else is doing it" a valid reason for unethical and immoral behavior? “Everyone else is doing it” is not itself a reason for any behavior. However if the behavior itself is not criminal, not against any code of ethics I’ve sworn to uphold, not immoral per my gigantically driving and minutely considered and examined conscience and lights, then the fact it may be illegal in another country, or against someone else’s code of ethics, or the fact another may consider it immoral is no reason for me not to do it. Mind you in the latter case, I’m keen to see the wrong they see, and often ask! Good discussions all around. You do realize individuals are not bound to doctors’, researchers’, lawyers’, accountants’, educators’ ethics when they are not doctors, researchers, lawyers, accountants or educators? These are higher standards of conduct than are relevant to the general public. The public entrusts these professionals with their lives and health, their case at law, their finances, their children, in ways that open up areas of potential abuse. Risks which the code of ethics is there to address. It’s a sales job on the public confidence: to reassure them their public trusts are not misplaced. To assure them “we see the specific risks entailed, and have sworn to uphold and enforce a higher standard.” A standard it would be ludicrous to apply to others, where those specific risks do not exist - hence “higher standard.” Higher in a way that is purposeful and apt. A professor having sex with the customers is concerning in a way an auto mechanic having sex with the customers is not, presuming all involved are adults. There is a dynamic of power and influence in the former case that creates the concern. I can tell right from wrong. Some people who claim this and that are moral or immoral literally can’t. What they say is wrong - what’s wrong with it? What does it risk, damage, diminish, destroy? What they say is right, what good is it? What does it create, enable, support, protect? If you can tell right from wrong, these questions have answers. The risks of wrong and benefits of right are considerable and demonstrable. “Tell” at the very least means “say,” if you mean to tell another. Another’s idea of immorality is wrong for me and immoral for me if they share it and share why - they can indeed say what’s wrong with what they call wrong - and I can see yes, this is considerable, demonstrable wrong. Otherwise? Otherwise, let’s just observe a person is free to find and value their own goods. To derive their right and wrong by what furthers or opposes those goods. Fair enough. If someone says something’s immoral and they have no idea why, that’s on them. They’re free to abhor and avoid it. I won’t say they’re immoral. They’ve got their own compass. If they can read it, it doesn’t matter if it’s cryptic and unreadable to others. Morality’s deepest and highest purpose is self-control, not to command, control, coerce and condemn others. We are not exactly helpless, at the mercy of others’ morality. Law is a subset of morality, in its criminal code. It contains all the worst, most wrong, most immoral acts - acts so wrong even the general public can see “Wow, that’s so bad we need to hire help to punish even ourselves if we do it.” Beyond the high, dotty line of law, we are all free to attempt…anything. Able to follow and so hone (in ownership of consequence) our own conscience, and not subject to another’s. These are both great goods, and hard to say which is the greater. Another cannot judge or punish you. Only we all can, only by the hired help, only for one of the listed judgeable, punishable acts, only via due process. Good setup. But no, “everybody else is doing it” is no reason for anyone to do anything. Just like “nobody else is doing it” is no reason not to. Just like “everybody else is doing it” is no reason not to. If you want reasons not to do something, you’re going to have to go deeper than a popularity survey.
